item.title: Some Information on #454
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“henry, post:19, topic:71634”]Yes that does help Mopar, and like Greeny said, anything educational would be greatly appreciated

And Mopar I didn’t realise that it changed the names of the methods and such I always thought it was just some ints somewhere that got changed… But how do you know what methods they are like get.Objects or whatever?[/quote]

Just one example off the top of my head, the only time you will find ‘* 31’ in the client is on the same line right next to the variables which store the current and max HP for a player. So an updater will look for patterns like that and tell you what the variable is named this week.

Read full topic

item.title: Some Information on #454
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

[quote=“henry, post:19, topic:71634”]Yes that does help Mopar, and like Greeny said, anything educational would be greatly appreciated

And Mopar I didn’t realise that it changed the names of the methods and such I always thought it was just some ints somewhere that got changed… But how do you know what methods they are like get.Objects or whatever?[/quote]

They updater will look for known patterns of code. After looking hard enough over several updates, someone sexy (like regex) will be able to see the patterns of code he needs to look for to for to find x method or x variable.

Read full topic

item.title: Some Information on #454
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“henry, post:16, topic:71634”]rofl, say i wanted to get into client hacking like this, wtf is the updater telling me and how is it useful

(dont flame me, im here to learn )[/quote]

Runescape changes the client on average every week, when it changes all of the methods/fields/classes renamed to some random combination of letters. If you want to write a bot, or anything useful with the client, you will need to know the new names of certain specific things every week, which is what an updater does, it searches for patterns and gives you the new names of the methods/fields/classes that you want.

Did that explain it enough? If not I’ll try again.

Read full topic

item.title: Some Information on #454
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

I agree with you frank_. However these are great if your struggling to find a variable and you want to look it up and figure out how to find it in the future. They’re also very useful if you’ve got a pattern that lasted say 5 versions and then broke. Saves alot of time. But like I said, your points are very valid and I agree with the majority of it.

Read full topic

item.title: Some Information on #454
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

The fields are extremely helpful, keep that up.

What isn’t useful is ‘Updated in ___ms’, the only time your code is running too slow is if you are sitting there waiting for it to finish going ‘shit! this sure is taking a long time’ (ie regex’s original aryan updater :P)

Read full topic

item.title: Some Information on #454
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

popcorn, as ive said before to many people on many occasions, if i believed that i knew enough to inform others i would, but i dont because i am of the opinion that the damage of misinformation far outweighs common knowledge

@ ollie, you may say that, though you do not believe it do you?
to be truly honest, it does impact somewhat on the way i code, for example, when finding the version of the client took over 30ms, i hunted down where it took so long, and modified it so that it doesnt even take half of that (though undoubtedly psb’s updater can determine the version before the class is even loaded, in the lighting fast speeds that it works :rolleyes: )

you could however adapt the times to be compared to previous client versions, as an insight into how effectively jagex are hiding the instructions that you seek

just for fun, before

private void getVersion() { ClassGen clazz = classes.get("client"); ConstantPoolGen cpg = clazz.getConstantPool(); Method m = clazz.containsMethod("main", "([Ljava/lang/String;)V"); MethodGen mg = new MethodGen(m, "client", cpg); InstructionList il = mg.getInstructionList(); for (Instruction i : il.getInstructions()) { if (i instanceof SIPUSH) { int val = ((SIPUSH) i).getValue().intValue(); if (val > 440 && val < 800 && val != 503 && val != 765) { version = val; return; } } } }

after

private void getVersion() { ClassGen clazz = classes.get("client"); ConstantPoolGen cpg = clazz.getConstantPool(); Method m = clazz.containsMethod("main", "([Ljava/lang/String;)V"); ByteSequence bytes = new ByteSequence(m.getCode().getCode()); try { Instruction i = Instruction.readInstruction(bytes); while (i != null) { if (i instanceof SIPUSH) { int val = ((SIPUSH) i).getValue().intValue(); if (val > 440 && val < 800 && val != 503 && val != 765) { version = val; return; } } i = Instruction.readInstruction(bytes); } } catch (IOException e) { e.printStackTrace(); } }this can probably be improved still

unlike others, i am not naive or stupid enough to believe that this counts as me helping people

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:

edit: also frank_, as said by many others, update time is not important

Read full topic

item.title: Some Information on #454
item.dc:creator: @popcorn89 popcorn89
item.description:
@popcorn89 wrote:

These topics are extremely helpful for someone wanting to get into client hacking, it gives them somewhere to start. I kind of agree with you in one point though, I’m not entirely sure what their motives are for posting this. But they’re still helping, something I haven’t seen you do much of at all.

Read full topic

item.title: Some Information on #454
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

i had no intention whatsoever of flaming until i saw the request not to, though i will keep myself mildly disgruntled.

there are only two useful purposes i can see for people posting this sort of data, one being, so that if a person’s updater fails and they truly have no idea what they are doing, they can find other usages of the variable so that they can grab it using another means. the other being that if they, again, had no idea what they were doing, but want to use reflection to pull this data.

however, the reason i presume these topics are continually posted is for the sake of self gratification, that is, showing how “brilliant” you are by determining a select few variables and comparing the epeen gained by having a lower update time

Read full topic
